title: German frigate Karlsruhe (F223)
text:
"Karlsruhe" (F223) is the fourth ship of the s of the <a href="German%20Navy">German Navy</a>. 
Design.
The Type 120 or "Köln"-class frigates were built as smooth-deckers and had very elegant lines. The very diagonally cut bow and the knuckle ribs in the foredeck made it easy to navigate. The <a href="Hull%20%28watercraft%29">hull</a> and parts of the <a href="superstructure">superstructure</a> were made of shipbuilding <a href="steel">steel</a>, other superstructure parts were made of <a href="Aluminium">aluminum</a>. Due to the installation of <a href="Gas%20turbine">gas turbines</a>, large side air inlets were necessary, which could be closed by lamellas. The stern was designed as a round stern. The large funnel was sloped and skirted. Behind the bridge superstructure stood the tall <a href="lattice%20mast">lattice mast</a> with <a href="radar">radar</a> and other <a href="Antenna%20%28radio%29">antennas</a>. The hull was divided into 13 watertight compartments. 
On the forecastle was a 10 cm gun, behind it, set higher, a 4 cm twin gun. Behind it stood two quadruple anti-submarine missile launchers 37.5 cm from Bofors. A 4 cm Bofors single gun on each side of the aft superstructure and another 4 cm double mount at the end of the superstructure. There was a second 10 cm gun on the quarterdeck. In addition, there were two 53.3 cm torpedo tubes behind the front superstructures. They were used to fire Mk-44 torpedoes. Mine rails were laid behind the torpedo tubes and ran to the stern. 
Construction and career.
"Karlsruhe" was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 29 October 1958 and <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 15 August 1959 in <a href="St%C3%BClcken%20%26amp%3B%20Sohn">Stülcken & Sohn</a>, Germany. She was <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 7 April 1962.
The "Karlsruhe" was sold to <a href="Turkish%20Naval%20Forces">Turkish Navy</a> after active service in the German Navy and since 28 March 1983 sailed there under the Turkish flag as the destroyer "Gazi Osman Pasa" with the identification D-360. 
In 1984 it was renamed "Gelibolu", but kept the Identification D-360. 
Her last decommissioning took place there on 27 June 1994.
